column2: The pikemen of the Rust Belt are trained to present an impenetrable wall of steel to enemy cavalry and infantry.
Here the knights of the South face off against each other in jousting tournaments and other chivalrous competitions.
he strong tradition of sharpshooting in the Gulf produces excellent bowmen. Here they can practice with their powerful longbows.
The agile light cavalry of the Mexican kingdoms are raised here. These horsemen are skilled in skirmishing and harassment.
The housecarls of the Great Lakes are trained here, providing excellent if somewhat ill-tempered heavy infantry, usually equipped with powerful battle axes.
Caribbean warriors are trained here in the use of machetes and cutlasses.
All Canadians can recruit elite pikemen in these rinks. Trained to fight defensively, they can provide a ruler with unyielding wall of spears.

All Canadians can recruit elite cavalrymen here. Having formed a good horse riding culture using the vast Canadian prairies, they are able to go toe-to-toe with the other martial horse-riding cultures in the region.
Arctic Territory soldiers are housed here, specializing in outmaneuvering and overcoming the enemy in the roughest terrain and coldest weather.
The open ports of ambitious pirate lords attract all manner of adventurers, deserters, criminals and desperados, all willing to set sail for plunder and booty.
Whalers dock here to properly process their sea-bounty for its meat and blubber. Both meat and blubber are important commodities that can be used for either trade or stored for upcoming winters.

The cowboys of the American West, the vaqueros of Mexico, the llaneros of Venezuela, and the gaúchos of the Southern Cone are excellent light cavalrymen, trained to hit the enemy relentlessly from different directions before regrouping and doing it again.
The militias of New York wield fearsome spiked staffs designed to dehorse knights. They have proven themselves more than once against armored cavalry.

The dragoons of Hudsonia are a fearsome sight on the battlefield, with both horse and rider clad in heavy steel armor, armed with lances or crossbows. Few armies can withstand one of their massed charges.
The Continental Guards of Philadelphia, Baltimore, and Washington are known for their resolve on the battlefield, able to fight at peak condition regardless of climate or terrain.
Originally from the Maritimes, the gallowglass warriors are excellent heavy infantrymen renowned for their stubborn defense.
Well-disciplined Uplander pike formations are raised here, specializing in defense.
The feared horse archers of the Great Plains are trained here. These highly mobile horsemen frequently outmaneuver their opponents, and are some of the finest warriors the world has ever seen.

The hardy and self-sufficient mountaineers of the Great Divide are trained to strike swiftly from ambush, especially when defending the rocky crags of their homeland. Their superior foraging skills reduce maintenance costs.
Californian wheeler soldiers travel by two-wheeled velocipede, but dismount before battle to serve as superheavy infantry armed with pikes and hammers.
The rangers of the Pacific Northwest use aggressive skirmish tactics to demoralize their foes, filling the sky with arrows and hunting the survivors with light cavalry.
The Wildmen of Nawlins are instantly recognizable by their elaborate feathered battle regalia and renowned for their discipline and bravery.
The guerrillas of the Central American jungles are known for their mobility, skill at ambush, and constant harassment of enemy forces.
Ballesteros are trained to wield and maintain powerful crossbows, which they use with lethal precision against even the most heavily armored foes.
Named for an ancient group of indigenous Brazilian warriors, the Tamoios are tenacious warriors that are known for their use of poison darts and blowguns in battle.
Named for the group of Jewish rebels who rose up against an oppressive empire long ago, the Maccabees are highly trained and heavily armored infantrymen armed with longswords and hammers.

Pirate captains and their crews dock here to rest, spend their gold, maintain their ships, and train for future raids. Brethren pirates are known and feared for their use of unconventional and underhanded tactics.
Native warriors from Eastern Woodland tribes are armed with tomahawks, bows, and gunstock-shaped war clubs. These soldiers are famous throughout Old America for their bravery and fighting spirit.
Maori warriors are famous for performing the "Haka", a ceremonial dance, before battles. This is done to motivate Maori warriors and intimidate their enemies.
The native peoples of the Pacific Northwest are known and feared for their heavy armors, whose rod-and-slat design can stand against the strongest of weapons.
Japanese Samurai warriors are known for their use of katanas and wakizashis in close-quarters combat, as well as their mastery of martial arts.
Russian Cossack horsemen train here. They are known for their strong independent streak, and they operate semi-autonomously from the rest of the Russian military.
Imported camels and their riders are trained here. Camel cavalry is highly effective in desert climates, but they tend to become significantly less effective when outside their natural habitat.

Soldiers from East Asia are known for their extensive use of crossbows. Crossbows are relatively rare in post-Event North America, making the sight of a full crossbow unit on the battlefield a fearsome one.
Peyote is a small cactus with psychoactive properties used for spiritual ceremonies.
Small, highly toxic creatures are hunted for their venom to be used in warfare.

Most Brazilian cavalry units can trace their history directly back to the dragoon regiments of the pre-Event Empire of Brazil. The Independence Dragoons are known for their rigid discipline and striking uniforms.
Cangaceiros from northeastern Brazil reside here. Using whatever weapons they can get their hands on, these nomadic bandits are feared for their guerrilla tactics and brutality towards their enemies.

These elite Chicagoan cavalry are famous for their intricate "wings" made out of different kinds of feathers from the birds of the great lakes. These cavalry would charge at the enemy with their modified lances while the "wings" made loud noises to frighten the enemy.

The Plautdietsch adopted the use of horses alongside their traditional use of pikes due to the terrain, allowing them to quickly move a pike formation across the battlefield. They sometimes charge with their modified pikes when the opportunity presents itself.
Expert use of riverboats and of the gaited horse breeds of the area makes for a fast-action response unit, often responding to river raids and invasions.
Pendekars are Malay warriors who have mastered every aspect of the martial art, Silat. This means that not only they are hardy warriors, but also capable of being a doctor and a teacher as well.

Based upon the ancient Imperial Guard or Zebenya of Ras-Tafari himself, Zebenyas are equipped with only the finest equipment. With their high-quality equipment and superior training, they are a formidable force in the battlefield.

The Caribbean lowlands of the Miskito Coast are dotted by numerous watch towers that are manned by expert watchmen or Aiwawakra in Miskito. Their duties are to give information on the enemies whereabouts and shadow their movements if need be. They would also serve as the first line of defence against invasion before friendly reinforcements arrive.
This elite cavalry men also acts as any town's official garrison, upholding order and providing good defence for the town.
The infamous machete wielding cavalry men, Mambises, are raised and trained here. Their devastating machete charge is a terrifying sight to behold.

This is the place where Filipino lower nobles, called Maharlika, gather in times of war. Although forced to answer any call to arms and obligated to provide their own arms at their own expense, they are unusually loyal in the case that they are the ones who have the larger share of the spoils.

The Awqaq Runas and Guecha warriors of the Incan and Muisca cultures respectively are highly trained in mountain warfare. Peppering their enemies with their various ranged weapons first, before charging in with fast moving mountain men makes them a formidable enemy to face.
The Atlatlists were super-specialized dart-throwers, employing a long, wooden, spear-like object to hurl their darts towards the intended target at a great speed.
The Solar Knights are elite Purepecha horsemen, supported by trained pikemen on their flanks. Those who face the Solar Knights in battle are lucky if they live to tell the tale.

This is where the elite of the Khalifi cavalry are recruited and trained. The Khalifis of California have a long tradition fielding some of the finest cavalry in the world - armed with lances, swords and bows. This would prove useful due to the harshness of the South Californian desert.

Equipped with heavy scale armour and decorative but heavy-duty spears, these Javidan or Immortals are a curious but fearsome sight on the battlefield. Rumored to be inspired by an ancient order of soldiers, during peacetime they wear decorative robes to signify the majesty of their liege. These warriors also tend to ride on horseback albeit lightly armored.

The heavy infantry of the Chiraqi and Prodnanici cultures is inspired by the nearby soldiers of the Rustbelt albeit equipped with large axes and swords instead of pikes. Here is where these elite warriors are trained and drilled to be ready for battle in the service of their liege.

Many young men dream to join the ranks of the Arabian Knights. These famous Knights are armed with lances, axes and bows. Due to their diverse weaponry, they have great tactical flexibility for the marshy terrain they see themselves in. Although, only the bravest are granted the title of Arabian Knight.

Keeping to their traditions while adapting to their current terrain, the Tali'ah are expert warriors. Their tactic of charging and disengaging repeatedly with fast-moving soldiers while mounted warriors chase down the routing army, will prove to be instrumental to their own survival.

This is where the famous Tlingit coin armor is made. The first versions of the armor are rumoured to be made of coins from an unknown land to the west, but now it is now mostly made of coins from the various realms in the west coast. Known to resist blades and arrows, one must be wary when facing a warrior donning the armor. The slight income boost is welcome as well.
The hardy warriors of the various Canadian plateaus have adapted to the surrounding cultures and are ready to fight for their land. They are equipped with heavy armor and trained in mounted archery.

Any smart person would know to avoid trespassing in Dene territory, for they would be greeted with a messy and unfortunate end. Dene warriors are known to wield big knives and they can certainly wield them with expertise.

The various sled dog breeds of the north has led to the cultures there to adopt them for use in warfare. The warriors, named Mushers, fight on sleds using various range weapons and when it comes to it, the dogs can be released to inflict damage and discord among enemy ranks.

The fearless warriors of the Eagle Jaguar orders are trained here. They represent the elite of the mesoamerican war machine and entire armies have been known to rout at the mere sight of the spotted fur covering their armor for the Jaguar warriors and the eagle heads that the Eagle warriors wear.
The strong tradition of archery in Mexican highlands produces excellent bowmen. Here they can practice with their powerful bows.

The various jungles of Mexico serves both as an advantage and disadvantage in regards to military capabilities. The lords who find themselves ruling lands in jungle terrain tend to use fast-moving and lightly armored soldiers suited to the terrain to defend their holdings.

While Rocklanders generally excel at mountain warfare, they sometimes find their troops unsuitable to other types of terrain. At this type of situation, they adapt to the terrain and employ mounted units to support their ambush tactics for a more generalist approach.

Californian mountain wheeler soldiers travel via reinforced velocipedes called Boneshakers, named due to uncomfortable ride that is caused by the very stiff materials used that grants the velocipede survivability against the mountainous elements. Because of the terrain and the mount, these soldiers mainly serve as lightly armoured skirmishers armed with swords, javelins, slings, and bows.

Californian desert soldiers travel via velocipedes modified for use in the desert, mainly enlarging the wheels. One should not let the funny looking mounts distract you from the riders dismounting equipped with swords, longswords, and hammers. Surprisingly, some of these mounts made their way to the snowy north and proved to be able to navigate the deep snow.

Claiming descent on an antediluvian Colombian warrior order, this academy is highly regarded for the warriors it produces. These warriors are mostly riding on horseback wielding lances but are also trained in mountain warfare
This temple has been dedicated to Washington, the first and greatest Founding Father.
This temple has been dedicated to Jefferson, the Founding Father representing free trade.
This temple has been dedicated to Roosevelt, who famously sailed around the world in his Great White Ship.
This temple has been dedicated to Lincoln, who ended the largest revolt in American history.
A curved wooden idol bearing deep religious significance for the local pagan tribes.
A twisted pillar made of rusted iron bearing deep religious significance for the local pagan tribes.
A carved mural depicting nightmarish creatures bearing deep religious significance for the local pagan tribes.
A small, glittering, pyramid-shaped structure bearing deep religious significance for the local pagan tribes.
A sacred carved pillar bearing deep religious significance for the local pagan tribes.
